I think y'all are taking the Cap'n a little too seriously...is it not okay for him to express his opinion that he's not interested in the torrent? Some people (like myself) like to archive files to a server and later stream them, often I download files and don't even watch them until I have company over and get a request...yes it's not a big deal but guess what there are a lot of scene releases on the internet, things like this are typically a deal breaker for me; if there's a better release available, then wouldn't I be remiss not to download the better file? Two cd's might be an indicator that the uploader is a novice, foreshadow errors in the media file, or lead me to think that the quality might be lower than otherwise hoped for. I DIDN'T SAY ANY OF THAT WAS APPLICABLE, I relate it to skimming a book for the important details. Further, it's not like he bitched and moaned, all he said was it wasn't for him. For some of you to attack him and call him ignorant is in itself ignorant, freedom of speech assholes. K I'm off the soapbox, thanks for the torrent hackulus

To watch it as one continuous film:

Drag the second file into the same folder as the first file, then open them via VLC, selecting both files (click on the first, then hold down shift then click on the second so both are highlighted, then press 'open'). VLC will automatically run the second one after the first one.

BR rips must be intended for 5.1 home theater systems, because as one poster stated, on a simple subwoofer / dual tweeter setup, the action scenes sound like explosions, yet the talking scenes are barely audible.  Had to crank the volume all the way up on my powered speakers just to hear the conversations. This is very frustrating for box dwellers who needs to appease their neighbors by keeping the sound low.  Are there better ways to rip the audio to retain an acceptable volume balance between vocals and action?
